story.title: #AskACurator 2014

author.name: British Museum
author.bio: A museum of the world, for the world.

image.caption: Don’t forget to send us your #AskACurator questions! Our first curator will join us at 10.00 BST #MemoriesOfANation http://t.co/PbpRgLiRjc

quote.text: Don’t forget to send us your #AskACurator questions! Our first curator will join us at 10.00 BST #MemoriesOfANation http://t.co/PbpRgLiRjc

image.caption: We're here with Barrie Cook, curator of our Germany exhibition #MemoriesOfANation opening 16 Oct. Send us questions! http://t.co/MXTEaUm7XK

quote.text: We're here with Barrie Cook, curator of our Germany exhibition #MemoriesOfANation opening 16 Oct. Send us questions! http://t.co/MXTEaUm7XK
@britishmuseum @AskACurator When you are putting together a new collection how do you try and tell a story? #AskACurator
Barrie says: exhibitions all start with an idea. Sometimes that idea is clear, objects just jump out at you...
...The Germany exhibition was not like this. The narrative and object list constantly evolved and changed completely throughout the planning
@britishmuseum #memoriesofanation What kinds of conversations with German museums/partners happened & how did they inform the curation?
It was a matter of figuring out what strengths the British Museum collection had, and then working out what we couldn't show (1/2)
But it was also a dialogue. The German museums incredibly generously loaned us objects that we hadn't initially considered...
...Sometimes we also asked for things and museums were hesitant about loaning, but many still agreed. Some also suggested great alternatives
@britishmuseum How do you create a thorough exhibition of ‘Germany’, when there were so many complex disparate kingdoms and cultures?
That is basically the question we were trying to answer, to represent this diversity of modern Germany's past through objects
It is inevitably a partial view, but we hope #MemoriesOfANation is interesting and maybe suprising
@britishmuseum #MemoriesOfANation hello Barry, which object was the most touching for you and which the most surprising to get exhibited?
We were very surprised and delighted to get Tischbein's portrait of Goethe from the @staedelmuseum - the most iconic German portrait
@britishmuseum #Memoriesofanation What objects do you think will be most unknown or surprising for a german viewer of the exhibition?
There were German curators working on the exhibition who found the local paper money 'Notgeld' of the early 20th century a revelation...
...They were excitedly finding scenes of their home towns on the notes.
@britishmuseum #memoriesofanation as universal vs national-historical museum, to what extent were Anglo-German relations over time a factor?
We decided that everything in the exhibition would be a German object and we are looking at Germany's memories of itself ...
... Occasionally the British dimension can inform this, however that wasn't our main approach.
@britishmuseum what were the biggest challenges of curating #MemoriesOfANation and which final outcome(s) are you/the BM most pleased with?
The biggest challenge of curating #MemoriesOfANation is the narrative, the structure to contain great objects in one room.
@britishmuseum @staedelmuseum Have you any sculptures by Tilman Riemenschneider? I ask partly because I like the name Tilman Riemenschneider
There is an altarpiece by Riemenschneider in the collection which is in Room 40, but not in the exhibition http://t.co/W7iNdKtHRE
But we are borrowing some magnificent Riemenschneider sculptures of the 4 evangelists from @smbmuseum which will be in #MemoriesOfANation
@britishmuseum was anything refused, and if so, why ?
We thought about the crown of the Holy Roman Empire, but by law it cannot leave Austria...
... There were a few refusals, usually because the object was promised elsewhere or for conservation reasons.
@MelanievonBraun @britishmuseum The cradle of Hochdeutsch the language that unified all Germans is the Luther Bible. Would be my key piece!
There will be a copy in #MemoriesOfANation of the 1541 edition of Luther's Bible with a dedication in his own hand, from @britishlibrary
@britishmuseum regarding #memoriesofanation...was there a 2nd choice for the 1st object visitors see when entering exhibition? #AskACurator
There are actually three 'first objects' - a VW Beetle in the Great Court, a piece of the Berlin Wall just outside the exhibition ...
... and the first thing you will see walking into the #MemoriesOfANation exhibition is a reunification banner from 1989 #AskACurator
Thanks to #MemoriesOfANation curator Barrie Cook for answering your #AskACurator questions! We'll have more curators here from 13.00 BST

image.caption: We’ve got more curators joining us this afternoon! We’re here with Citi Money Gallery Curator Ben Alsop #AskACurator http://t.co/JOrwIl0O04

quote.text: We’ve got more curators joining us this afternoon! We’re here with Citi Money Gallery Curator Ben Alsop #AskACurator http://t.co/JOrwIl0O04
#AskACurator if you had to 'job swap' for a week what other museum would you fancy a bash at?
Curator Ben says: I would love to work at @railwaymuseum in York - a childhood dream. #AskACurator
@PetrieMuseEgypt @britishmuseum How do you gain the experience to be a curator or other paid museum jobs? #Askacurator
I volunteered at my local Museum in Bedford. I also visited many different museums and completed an MA in Museums & Artefact Studies (1/2)
But of course there are many different routes to becoming a curator and a bit of luck always helps! (2/2) #AskACurator
@britishmuseum #askacurator What are the essential passions you must have to become a curator?
A love of history and a passion for its coolest area of study numismatics! #AskACurator
Thanks to Citi Money Gallery Curator Ben Alsop for answering your #AskACurator questions. We've got more curators coming up soon!

image.caption: We’re now joined by #AfricanRockArt Curator Elizabeth Galvin @LisaGalvin_BM. Send us your questions! #AskACurator http://t.co/qA20kC6xUP

quote.text: We’re now joined by #AfricanRockArt Curator Elizabeth Galvin @LisaGalvin_BM. Send us your questions! #AskACurator http://t.co/qA20kC6xUP
#AskACurator What was the biggest change in curating since 10years ago? @museumtrier @hdg_museen @HistMuseumBs @MuseumTweetup @britishmuseum
Curator Elizabeth says: Digital objects are a big way museum collections have changed recently. I have 25,000 objects on a hard drive!
@britishmuseum @LisaGalvin_BM #AskACurator what is your favourite story about the discovery of a piece of African rock art?

image.caption: I have many favourite stories. We just wrote a piece about the Crying Cows in Algeria ... http://t.co/1cXoySOkdD http://t.co/a06s4PR5Fl

quote.text: I have many favourite stories. We just wrote a piece about the Crying Cows in Algeria ... http://t.co/1cXoySOkdD http://t.co/a06s4PR5Fl
... A local myth states that a shepherd carved these 7,000-8,000-year-old engravings because he was looking for water for his cattle
@rijksmuseum @metmuseum @britishmuseum Don't you think museums should create a new way to access collection online ?
Especially with digital collections e.g. #AfricanRockArt People worldwide can virtually explore these fantastic works http://t.co/Q7Pi1KZUTw
@britishmuseum @LisaGalvin_BM #AskACurator #AfricanRockArt is it art or archaeology?
It's art and archaeology... and anthropology, history, conservation science & many more! You can't look at it in a vacuum of one discipline
RT @AllaRustica: @britishmuseum #AskACurator What item have you touched that has brought you to tears?

image.caption: It breaks my heart when I see someone destroying thousands of years worth of our human history in rock art http://t.co/wMnAtF0A1O

quote.text: It breaks my heart when I see someone destroying thousands of years worth of our human history in rock art http://t.co/wMnAtF0A1O
@britishmuseum @LisaGalvin_BM that is so fantastic ! What a dream job! What is your favorite part about your job? #AskACurator
My favourite part of my job is watching a visitor connect with an object in the Museum or online and seeing history in a new way
@britishmuseum Any books or articles you recommend to learn more about African Rock Art before my next trip to London! ?
Our #AfricanRockArt project website has a lot of info & resources about rock art and we are continually adding to it http://t.co/Q7Pi1KZUTw
#AskACurator What is your academic background and/or former experience? @gonzagauthier @britishmuseum @V_and_A @MuseeOrsay @AshmoleanMuseum
I'm an anthropologist. I've worked with museums throughout Africa, but mainly in southern and eastern Africa @LisaGalvin_BM #AskACurator
@britishmuseum #AskaCurator Most of us give museum objects a passing glance. Any tips as to how we might really look & learn?
I like to think about the person who made the object. How would they have worn it, held it or used it in their daily life? #AskACurator

image.caption: Thanks to Curator Elizabeth Galvin @LisaGalvin_BM. Find out more about #AfricanRockArt here http://t.co/Q7Pi1KZUTw http://t.co/tenuMOqu20

quote.text: Thanks to Curator Elizabeth Galvin @LisaGalvin_BM. Find out more about #AfricanRockArt here http://t.co/Q7Pi1KZUTw http://t.co/tenuMOqu20

image.caption: We’re here now with #8mummies Curator John Taylor. Send us your #AskACurator questions! http://t.co/IJADqSFeed

quote.text: We’re here now with #8mummies Curator John Taylor. Send us your #AskACurator questions! http://t.co/IJADqSFeed
@britishmuseum @NHM_London i wants to know how they drainout the brain from the body.. I mean i've never seen any hole in skull of any mummy
Curator John says: they pushed a rod up the nose and broke the small bones inside the nostril ...
... and used a metal hook to pull the brains through the nose in pieces #AskACurator
@britishmuseum #AskACurator do any of the museum objects have a ghostly or spooky connection

image.caption: The Unlucky Mummy (it's really a coffin) was supposed to bring bad luck to anyone who owned it http://t.co/wKxF6M3TBR http://t.co/BkbS2Qog4h

quote.text: The Unlucky Mummy (it's really a coffin) was supposed to bring bad luck to anyone who owned it http://t.co/wKxF6M3TBR http://t.co/BkbS2Qog4h
The Unlucky Mummy is said to have been on the Titanic when it sank, but that's not true! #AskACurator
@britishmuseum hello ! Q1: What's your secret weapon to bring kids & families to explore your museum ? #AskACurator
We know that kids love mummies and so we've provided ways for families to engage with the #8mummies exhibition http://t.co/7VZbjwYBOn
@britishmuseum #AskACurator did you find anything unexpected when you did the scans ? Amulets deformities etc?
When we looked at the scans of one mummy's skull from #8mummies we found part of the tool which the embalmer was using to remove the brain
@britishmuseum will a museum ever again cut open a mummified person or animal? #8mummies #AskACurator
Our policy is not to open any mummies. Instead in #8mummies we used CT scanning to find out what's inside them
@britishmuseum What is the most rewarding part of your job? #AskACurator

image.caption: Being the first person in 3,000 years to see what is inside a mummy is amazingly exciting #AskACurator http://t.co/RqrfR42OfR

quote.text: Being the first person in 3,000 years to see what is inside a mummy is amazingly exciting #AskACurator http://t.co/RqrfR42OfR
@britishmuseum what degree/training did you have to take to become a curator? #AskACurator
I have a degree and a doctorate in Egyptology and I built up experience in field archaeology, lecturing and writing #AskACurator
@britishmuseum #AskACurator #AskaDo you own objects made with mummy brown(the pigment made with ground up mummys)?
Not that I know of. The British Museum has not unwrapped a mummy for over 200 years #AskACurator
@britishmuseum #AskACurator How many people are on the team for the #8mummies exhibition? Is this the general norm of team numbers?
There are many people who work on an exhibition like #8mummies. Curators, conservators, designers, technicians, IT specialists ...
... hospital scanning staff, computer specialists, photographers, press and marketing teams and many others! #AskACurator
@britishmuseum What's the usual day for a curator in the midst of preparing an exhibit? #AskACurator
Everything from choosing objects to supervising conservation and photography, writing catalogues and exhibition labels ... #AskACurator

image.caption: ... and even meeting celebrities interested in ancient Egypt like @katyperry #AskACurator http://t.co/1MAsBh9Z8R

quote.text: ... and even meeting celebrities interested in ancient Egypt like @katyperry #AskACurator http://t.co/1MAsBh9Z8R
@britishmuseum #AskACurator How long does it usually take to prepare an exhibition?
It varies according to the content of the exhibition. Most take at least 2-3 years preparation but we have created some in under a year
Thanks to #8mummies Curator John Taylor for answering your #AskACurator questions! Next up: our #Ming50Years curators at 16.00 BST

image.caption: Don't forget to book tickets for #MemoriesOfANation http://t.co/LlVjIEzKma and #8mummies http://t.co/WoyNYBnQ8x now! http://t.co/Uus2ZbxP1m

quote.text: Don't forget to book tickets for #MemoriesOfANation http://t.co/LlVjIEzKma and #8mummies http://t.co/WoyNYBnQ8x now! http://t.co/Uus2ZbxP1m

image.caption: We are now with #Ming50Years curators Jessica Harrison-Hall and Yu-Ping Luk. Send us your #AskACurator questions! http://t.co/NgvklCsdYI

quote.text: We are now with #Ming50Years curators Jessica Harrison-Hall and Yu-Ping Luk. Send us your #AskACurator questions! http://t.co/NgvklCsdYI
@britishmuseum #AskACurator how do exhibitions such as #Ming50Years come to London and for how long are you planning?
This exhibition is the result of an original idea 5 years ago, conceived together with @CraigClunas from Oxford University #AskACurator
Should #museums be telling attractive stories about 'mundane' objects rather than enticing visitors in with attractive objects? #AskACurator
The #Ming50Years exhibition combines the mundane and the beautiful to tell stories about an important part of Chinese history
@britishmuseum #AskACurator Why is photography usually allowed in galleries but forbidden in exhibitions?
#Ming50Years includes loans from 30 different lenders. The flash photography can damage the delicate paintings and other fragile objects
Favourite eras in history you wish you knew more about? #AskACurator @britishmuseum
Curator Yu-Ping says: the mid-Ming period is not as well known as other eras of Ming history and I would like to know more about it (1/2)
Curator Jessica says: I would like to know more about the northern Song dynasty - another great period of Chinese imperial history
@britishmuseum #AskACurator What was you defining moment that help you decide you wanted to be a curator?
Curator Jessica says: volunteering at the British Museum and working with inspirational curators made me want to follow in their footsteps
@britishmuseum #askacurator How many exhibit ideas do you go through before you find the perfect one? Who comes up with the ideas/concepts?
There are many different ways of developing exhibition ideas - some come from the Director, others from the curators ... #AskACurator
... #Ming50Years was an idea that came from Jessica and @CraigClunas. It has taken 5 years and many people to develop that idea esp Yu-Ping
@britishmuseum #AskACurator- what would you change in the #Ming50Years if you did it again?
We would do a sequel, 1450-1500. #AskACurator
@britishmuseum what is the most fascinating thing you have learned while researching your current exhibition artifacts?#AskACurator

image.caption: That eunuchs played football before the emperor in the Forbidden City gardens, seen here in this #Ming50Years scroll http://t.co/4hwPrccCuw

quote.text: That eunuchs played football before the emperor in the Forbidden City gardens, seen here in this #Ming50Years scroll http://t.co/4hwPrccCuw
@britishmuseum What's the usual day for a curator in the midst of preparing an exhibit? #AskACurator

image.caption: No two days are the same. Today we tasted the #Ming50Years inspired menu at the Great Court restaurant. Delicious http://t.co/BrJQH9hjZA

quote.text: No two days are the same. Today we tasted the #Ming50Years inspired menu at the Great Court restaurant. Delicious http://t.co/BrJQH9hjZA
Other days we are working on writing books, like the Ming: 50 years that changed China book published this week http://t.co/Un67W2rX2S
@britishmuseum Has an exhibition display ever come to you in a dream? #AskACurator

image.caption: No, but the #Ming50Years exhibition has beautiful gem-encrusted gold pillow ends http://t.co/61LbGxv55O

quote.text: No, but the #Ming50Years exhibition has beautiful gem-encrusted gold pillow ends http://t.co/61LbGxv55O
Thanks to #Ming50Years Curators Jessica and Yu-Ping. Don't forget #Ming50Years opens tomorrow! http://t.co/3CZMG95TNm http://t.co/UUB9AjkWVL
